did.head: Collection Overview
did.unittitle: Ludmil A.Chotkowski Papers

repository.label: Location:
repository.corpname: Connecticut Polish American Archives, Elihu Burritt Library, Central Connecticut State University

did.abstract: The papers of Ludmil A. Chotkowski, a Polish American physician and vice-president of the Solidarity International, Connecticut Chapter, a grass root organization supporting underground and dissident activities in Poland in the 1980s. He initiated a successful campaign to erect the Popieluszko Human Rights Monument in New Britain, Conn. He was involved in lobbying efforts and media campaigns on behalf of Polish opposition and participated in activities of other anti-communist and pro-democracy organizations based in the USA.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Ludmil Adam Chotkowski, M.D. - born in Kensington, Conn. on May 19th, 1916 died on October 6th, 2005. he held a BS from Trinity College (1938), and a MD from Yale University (1942). He served with USAR Medical Corps from 1942 to 1944. Dr. Chotkowski, an internist, practiced in Berlin, Conn. and served as a state medical examiner, police surgeon, school physician and health director. He initiated many projects related to public health and environmental safety. He was an early crusader for open-space and anti-sprawl conservation efforts. In the 1980s he was one of the founders of and then vice-president and spokesman of a grass-root organization called the Solidarity International, Connecticut Chapter; co-chairman of Popieluszko Human Rights Monument Committee in New Britain in 1984-1989; a participant of the International Human Rights Conference in Krakow in 1988; and active in several human rights, pro-democracy and anti-communist organizations in the US.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The Collection contains materials related to the Solidarity International Connecticut Chapter, one of the many American and Western European grass-root organizations that supported Polish underground Solidarity movement and operated between 1982 and 1989. Among Solidarity International initiatives documented in this collection are: media campaigns, political lobbying and fundraising, erection of Popieluszko Human Right Monument in New Britain, Conn. And donation of Mercedes-Benz van for Lech Walesa. The collection also includes documents from the International Human Rights Conference in Krakow, Poland in 1988 and Mr. Chotkowski meeting with Lech Walesa; materials related to his involvement in several American anti-communist or pro-democracy organizations targeting other regions of the world. Materials include: correspondence, financial records, press releases, clippings, statements, programs, minutes, audiotapes, videotape, a medal, and a model of Popieluszko monument.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Cite as: Ludmil A. Chotkowski Papers (CPAA 90-14), Connecticut Polish American Archives, Elihu Burritt Library, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain

processinfo.p: Processed by Ewa Wolynska and Renata Vickrey, 2008

Artifacts: 3-D model of Popieluszko Human Rights Monument signed "HFC '86"; dimensions: flame-like structure 35 cm high on 26 x 22 sextagonal base, pedestal: 42 cm in diameter x 5 cm high, filled with rocks and 11.5 x 12.5 cm brass medal in shape of Poland; front : Father Jerzy Popieluszko face with cross imposed over it; reverse: an excerpt from his last sermon delivered in Bydgoszcz on Oct. 19th, 1984
